Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project: Data Science eXtension (DSX): Incorporating data science fundamentals in computing curriculum at Spelman and Morehouse Colleges

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Spelman College and Morehouse College seeks to address the need for skilled data scientists through data science and big data training for faculty and students at both colleges in partnership with the College of Charleston's Data Science program. The activities and strategies are evidence-based and a strong plan for formative and summative evaluation is part of the project.

The project has the specific goals to: train faculty on data science principles that are part of computing fundamentals and infuse the existing curriculum to showcase the data science principles; develop and implement a data science curriculum at the undergraduate level at both institutions; and broaden awareness of data science to students underrepresented in the discipline at the undergraduate level in preparation of graduate studies or corporate positions in data science. Two groups of ten faculty will be trained in data science principles, and these faculty will create, infuse and deliver data science modules to about 500 of their students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This HBCU-UP Targeted Infusion Project Data Science eXtension (DSX) project?s impact centers the data science education discussions and strategies on broadening participation in this emergent and in-demand discipline. This broadening participation includes increasing the number of Black college students who are exposed to the field, expanding perceptions of data science beyond computer science, mathematics and statistics and setting the stage for HBCUs as viable places to deliver data science instruction. We engaged with more than 20 faculty in supporting the design and development at least 20 courses across STEM, Business, Humanities and Social Science disciplines. As a result, nearly 250 students were directly exposed to our data science intervention model. Over 80% of the students who completed the post-instruction survey agreed that data science was relevant in their undergraduate matriculation plus they were willing to further their data science instruction. And also, 76% of student respondents agreed that their interest had increased. 

Data science skills impact multiple industries, such as finance and insurance, healthcare, information, real estate, retail and trade disciplines, management of companies, professional services and transportation and warehousing. Data science principles are represented in many academic fields like applied statistics, biology, business analytics, business intelligence, chemistry, computer science, data analytics, data mining and management information systems.

The DSX project leans into the interdisciplinary origins of data science. We accomplished this in three ways: (1) train faculty about data science principles that are part of computing fundamentals and enhance existing curriculum to showcase the data science principles, (2) develop and implement data science curriculum at the undergraduate level and (3) Broaden awareness of data science to underrepresented minorities at the bachelor?s level in preparation of graduate studies and/or corporate positions in data science careers. We?ve been successful in exposing data science in a targeted and accessible way at small institutions. 

The DSX project focused on the faculty through a faculty professional development program. The intent is to enhance, not replace, existing lectures and/or labs with data science principles in their courses. The program was executed in two phases. In phase I, faculty participated in a 10-day summer experience where presented data science as a spectrum of core skills and abilities with domain-specific uses. The 10-day summer workshop consists of a set of interactive guided work sessions. In phase II, monthly sessions were held throughout the academic year to assist faculty participant in their curriculum development. Additionally, we covered the intricacies of data collection, data cleanup, storage, management, analytics, visualization and communication in both phases. 

More details of the data science course module structure, faculty development program and lessons learned are further details in publications.
